awd_titl_txt: Experimental and Theoretical Studies toward the Development of New Corrosion-Resistant Steels and Corrosion Inhibitors for Reinforced Concrete Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Corrosion of steel reinforcement is one of the most prevalent deterioration mechanisms in concrete structures. Annual cost of corrosion of civil infrastructure in the United States is estimated to be around $25 billion, and a large part of this amount is ascribable to steel corrosion in concrete. Therefore it is critical to develop innovative, inexpensive, and ubiquitously effective corrosion mitigation strategies in the form of new corrosion-resistant steels and corrosion inhibitors. Trial-and-error procedures to produce new and affordable materials to resist steel corrosion in concrete have been, to a large degree, ineffective. The development of these new materials has also been hindered by the gaps in the fundamental understanding of steel corrosion in concrete and the lack of tools to intelligently design and test new materials. The combined experimental and theoretical approach of the present work will provide the tools and knowledge to bridge this gap. This research will have far reaching social, political and economic impacts by enabling researchers and material developers with the fundamental tools to hypothesize, design, optimize, and test new materials to mitigate issues associated with steel corrosion in reinforced concrete structures in a cost effective way.

The ultimate goal of the present research is to combine molecular dynamics simulations, first-principles calculations and experimental nano-scale material characterization techniques to make transformational contributions to the understanding of passivity and depassivation processes of steels in concrete and to create the required knowledge base and tools to develop inexpensive but highly effective new corrosion-resistant steels and corrosion inhibitors. Passivity, depassivation and corrosion of steel in concrete are atomic/molecular scale phenomena that take place within a 10-20 nanometer layer on the metal surface. Therefore, the fundamental understanding and the tools to design and test new materials need to be developed by combining nano-scale material characterization techniques and molecular level calculations. Based on the new insights provided by these techniques small, inexpensive and effective compositional changes on conventional steels can be made to increase their corrosion resistance or custom-designed corrosion inhibitors can be designed to slow down or prevent corrosion. In pursuit of these goals, the study follows a multi-disciplinary approach that brings together expertise from corrosion science, cement/concrete chemistry, electrochemistry, metallurgy, applied mathematics, numerical modeling, surface analysis and theoretical chemistry.

por.por_cntn:
Corrosion of steel reinforcement is one of the most prevalent deterioration mechanisms in concrete structures. Annual cost of corrosion of civil infrastructure in the United States is estimated to be around $25 billion, and a large part of this amount is ascribable to steel corrosion in concrete. Therefore, it is critical to develop innovative, inexpensive, and ubiquitously effective corrosion mitigation strategies in the form of new corrosion-resistant steels and corrosion inhibitors. Trial-and-error procedures to produce new and affordable materials to resist steel corrosion in concrete have been, to a large degree, ineffective. The development of these new materials has also been hindered by the gaps in the fundamental understanding of steel corrosion in concrete and the lack of tools to intelligently design and test new materials.

Corrosion initiation takes place in atomistic scale; therefore, the fundamental understanding and the tools to design and test new materials need to be developed by combining nano-scale material characterization techniques and atomistic simulation methods. This research used such an approach by combining two atomistic simulation techniques with highly specialized nano-scale experimental studies. One of the atomistic modeling techniques, Reactive Force Field Molecular Dynamics, allowed us to simulate the dynamic processes that take place during corrosion initiation in relatively large molecular scales that can be correlated to physical systems. The second modeling technique, Density Functional Theory, allowed us to generate input data for the Molecular Dynamics simulations and answer fundamental questions related to electron-structure interactions using first principles calculations. The data obtained from nano-scale experimental were used to validate the simulations. We were able to explain, in atomistic scale, how reinforcement in concrete is typically protected in concrete, and the conditions that might perturb this protection. Specifically, we explained how chloride-containing salts, from de-icing chemicals or marine environments, alter the surface of the metal to initiate corrosion.

We disseminated our findings through dissertations, peer-reviewed journal articles, oral and poster presentations at conferences, as well as invited talks in professional and research meetings. We expect that the technical outcomes of this research will have far-reaching social, political and economic impacts by enabling researchers and material developers with the fundamental tools to hypothesize, design, optimize, and test new materials to mitigate issues associated with steel corrosion in reinforced concrete structures in a cost effective way.

This project supported three doctoral students coming from three different training backgrounds: civil engineering, chemical engineering, and materials science. These students were trained in a truly interdisciplinary setting that combined corrosion science, cement chemistry, computational materials science, and surface/interface science. Furthermore, this project included outreach to underrepresented high school students through SESEY, a week-long summer camp on the Oregon State University campus. The participants were involved in various activities to introduce them to the broad world of science and engineering. During the 2017-18 summer term, we hosted two students in our laboratories and introduced them to computer programming and simulations. The students received hands-on experience in computational material science and had many opportunities to explore the power of programming and computation with simple calculations that could be verified by experimental data.

This research required extensive computational resources. We received research allocation on the Extreme Science and Engineering Discovery Environment (XSEDE) platform to support our computational efforts, molecular simulations of surface reactions, and surface interactions. XSEDE is supported by National Science Foundation grant number ACI-1548562. We benefited greatly from these NSF-funded computational resources.
